After completing high school, she enrolled in the American Academy of Dramatic Arts in New York City, where she honed her acting skills and began landing small roles on stage and screen.

In the early 1950s, Kelly began to gain recognition for her performances in films such as "The Country Girl" (1954) and "Rear Window" (1954), opposite Alfred Hitchcock. In 1955, Kelly married Prince Rainier III of Monaco, and became Her Serene Highness, Princess of Monaco. She stepped back from her acting career to focus on her royal duties, although she continued to make occasional appearances in films and documentaries.

As Princess of Monaco, Kelly was a beloved figure around the world, known for her elegance, intelligence, and philanthropic work. She died in a car accident on September 14, 1982, at the age of 52, leaving behind a legacy as one of Hollywood's most iconic actresses and a beloved princess.

Born on November 12, 1929, in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, Grace Kelly was an American actress who captivated the hearts of millions with her stunning looks, elegance, and remarkable talent. Kelly's breakthrough role came in 1951 with the film "Fourteen Hours," which was followed by a string of successful movies, including "High Noon," "The Country Girl," and "Rear Window" (directed by Alfred Hitchcock). Her iconic portrayal of Princess Alexandra in "High Society" (1956) further solidified her status as a Hollywood star.

In 1955, Kelly met Prince Rainier III of Monaco while filming "To Catch a Thief." The two exchanged correspondence, and Kelly eventually visited Monaco. She fell deeply in love with the charming prince, and on April 19, 1956, they married at the Cathédrale de Monaco.

After marrying Prince Rainier, Kelly became the Princess of Monaco, a title she held until her death on September 14, 1982, following a car accident in Monaco. During her time as princess, Kelly dedicated herself to philanthropic work, particularly in the fields of education and children's welfare.

Throughout her life, Kelly was renowned for her poise, grace, and generosity. She is still celebrated as a Hollywood legend, a devoted princess, and an inspiration to many around the world.
